Title.evidence: Invasive Hemodynamic Monitoring in Acute Heart Failure: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Eligible participants were adults diagnosed with AHF or CS.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received complete hemodynamic assessment, while the control group received standard care.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in hemodynamic stability, measured over a 30-day period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised using a computer-generated sequence and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 98 participants were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: showing a significant improvement in hemodynamic stability (mean difference = 5.2 mm Hg, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects.

Funding.evidence: Funding: This trial was funded by the National Heart Institute.
